conclusion: The tension force of spring B on object A is equal to the gravitational force of A.
Write the equation T = mg where T is the tension force, m is the mass of A, and g is the acceleration due to gravity.
Since spring B is in equilibrium, the force exerted by spring B is equal to the tension force, so k1 x = mg.
Given m = 2 kg, k1 = 200 N/m, and g = 9.8 m/s².
Substitute values into the equation to get 200x = 2 * 9.8, leading to x = 0.098 m.
The displacement of spring B is 0.098 m.
Consider spring C, which is pulled horizontally to position b, changing its length.
Write the equation L = a + b for the length of spring C.
Given a = 0 m and b = 0.6 m.
Substitute values into the equation to get L = 0 + 0.6, leading to L = 0.6 m.
The length of spring C is 0.6 m.
Since spring C is in equilibrium, the force exerted by spring C is equal to the tension force, so k2 ΔL = T.
Given T = 19.6 N and ΔL = 0.6 m.
Substitute values into the equation to get k2 * 0.6 = 19.6, leading to k2 = 32.67 N/m.
The spring constant of spring C is 32.67 N/m.
The height that object A rises is 0.098 m, and the spring constant of spring C is 32.67 N/m.
